Description: Terracotta figure of Athena Dadouchos. Athene Dadouchos, standing, holding a large torch to her right side, and supporting an oval shield with her lowered left hand. She wears a medium-length girt chiton with overfall, and an aegis: the gorgoneion is very worn. Her hair is parted in the centre and is brushed back over her ears, and she has a crested helmet with chevron decoration on its face above the brim, with a raised circle on the front of the plume-holder; lappets fall onto her shoulders from below the helmet. The shield, which has a ring-shaped boss, rests on an object now incomplete, perhaps an altar: its lower part, together with Athene’s feet and the plinth, are lost. The back is largely plain, only the helmet plume being indicated. A hole at the top of the torch has signs of burning, showing its use as an incense-holder. Hollow; two-piece mould. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt, with traces on the front of a white dressing.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV Comparanda. Close: Breccia 1934: no. 138 (torch largely lost) = LIMC ii (2): pl. 766:7. Similar, but with a branching double torch: d’Aigle Tremblay 1994: 9, figs 1–3; Philipp 1972: fig. 29, excavated at Theadelphia and dated c. ad 200. Similar, with single torch, but Athene much stouter: Dunand 1990: no. 12 (= Del Francia Barocus 1998: 62: no. 27), from Antinoopolis, dated second to third century ad; Dunand 1990: no. 13, dated Roman period = Willems and Clarysse 2000: 271: no. 202, dated second to third century ad; Ewigleben and von Grumbkow 1991: no. 72; Perdrizet 1921: no. 166, from Middle Egypt. Bibliog. Fischer 1994: no. 937.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3332)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
